reviewText:
Gun Monkeys is a 2D deathmatch game, though a rather uniquely designed one.  Rather than just killing eachother, it's a battle to drop your enemy's energy to 0 while keeping yours above that.  In addition to combat, you can collect energy to deposit into your generator and collecting enough will drop your opponent's energy as well.  All of this takes place in randomly generated levels which unfortunately aren't always balanced, often only spawning energy on one side of the map or placing one player's generator in a very difficult to use location.

Unfortunately the problems don't end there.  For a multiplayer-only game the netcode is terrible with frequent hit detection problems, disappearing energy, and being hit by explosions by entering the area several seconds after it happened.  The platforming is well designed, but is often clumsy in practice due to the random generation.

Despite these problems, the game is quite fun.  It looks great, has great music, and plenty of player customization to work with.  It unfortunately never took off and has very few active players but if you have some friends to play with, it's well worth your time.

reviewText:
Gun Monkeys is a 2D platformer in which you play against an opponent in a 1v1 arena match featuring monkey characters. During the match you have to collect cubes and return them to your base in order to increase your points. You are also equipped with a gun that you can use to kill your opponent, decreasing their points. You start at 200 points that decrease naturally over time and the match stops when one of the players reaches 0 points. There are different power ups that you can use and you also have the ability to drop bombs that explode your opponent. The points that you gain after winning a match can be used out of combat to purchase extra perks (speed boosts, more jumps, higher jumps etc.)

One good thing about this game is that you have the option of playing local co-op matches; since the official servers are not populated at all (you can usually find maximum 10 people that you can invite to play with, and these spread over the 4 servers while trying to get some Playfire rewards). This is why it’s probably best aquired as a 2-pack, with the intention on playing it with a friend.

I also liked the idea of the Monkey Fever achievement – you get this achievement only by playing against someone that already has it.

One downside of this game is the controls: jumps that don’t react properly to the keyboard input, and sometimes wall climbing or wall gripping fails. Due to these issues, getting the Cheeky Monkey achievement (which requires you to make a perfectly timed and extremely tight jump) was really frustrating to me (it took me 40 mins – 1h of repetitive jumps to finally get it). The network synchronization is also lacking – sometimes you can see the opponent at low health when they are in fact at almost full health.

Gun Monkeys doesn’t offer much content or replay value. It might be fun for a few matches but not more; I would recommend getting it during a sale (if you don’t have it already – who doesn’t even? it’s been in tons of sales / bundles / free promotions).

If you have a friend willing to go afk during the matches, you can get 100% in around 4h. Otherwise, it will take a lot more time if you decide to play against other people since they won’t let you win that easily and a match might take quite long (more than 5 minutes).

The concept seems amazing, the game seemed fun... however its multiplayer is 100% dead and all I could play was the tutorial. Therefore, based on what limited amount of the game I could play, I will tell you the Pros and Cons.

Pros:
♦ Awesome remapable controls (Every game needs remapable controls as easy as Gun Monkeys!)
♦ Great team colour settings (Pretty much any colour you want, you can be)

Cons:
♦ Alt+Tab caused game to crash on numerous occasions (This shouldn't happen for any reason)
♦ Idle changes resolution to something random (This is annoying as it doesn't change it native to your current resolution settings and doesn't change the resolution back upon closing)
♦ Servers register people into them making them say full or busy when they are empty (This is terrible as it registers a plyer to a server even when the person is offline making a server look active when it's 100% dead)

Overall, from the tutorial and farming cards, this seems like it would be a decent PvP 2D Platformer style game. reviewText:
I got this game when it was being offered for free, and I do not regret picking it up.

If you like 2-dimensional, 1-versus-1 gameplay, then you may enjoy this game.

The aesthetics are very nice with lots of special effects when you use different weapons or mines. During battle, the backdrop is always very bloomy and fun to look at. The music is very good and keeps you pumped during gameplay. Narration is provided during the tutorials and is very, very well done.

Controls are easy to pick up and the tutorial is extremely helpful for understanding how the game works. Learning curve is minimal to moderate - one of the hardest things will be deciding which perks to buy first (depends on your playstyle).

Pre-battle, you can select a lobby and chat with other uses. To challenge someone to a duel, you simply click ont their name - hovering over their name provides statistics like number of games played, win percentage, and equipped perks (up to 4 at a time).

During a battle, you are tasked with lowering the opponent's battery cell to 0. You can do this by picking up energy squares that will randomly spawn on the map (you can hold up to 3 at a time) and returning this to your base. This will boost your battery's health while also damaging your opponent's. Furthermore, you can also kill your opponent to reduce their battery by 35 points. The respawn time is not to long, however, there is a delay before your character can move after you spawn.

You can use proximity mines and your weapon to try to kill your opponent, as well as the random item pickups. They can either be weapon or power boosts (perks can help increase the rate of either item boost). The variation between weapons and power boosts is decent, and obtaining either can give you a serious edge over your opoonent (ex: a heavy rifle that does considerably more damage). Weapon drops have a certain number of ammunitation before you revert back to your original gun.

The levels are randomly generated and usually littered with ladders and floating platforms. As a monkey, you can wall jump indefinitely so long as you keep doing it (and have a wall).

A fun 1v1 game if you are interested in this playstyle. Will definitely keep you occupied for a good deal of time.

Recommend.

reviewText:
Well... I guess it's time to write my review since I cannot find any matches anymore and it is useless to keep the game on my computer anymore.

First the good things:

Tutorial:Short, straight to the point, funny voice actor. Great tutorail !

Unlockables:A huge variety of them. They suit every playstyle. Grinding for the higher perks is not required and the default ones work fine as well. In other words: everyone is equal and the perks don't make someone more overpowered than the other.

Level design:Great level design. The randomness of choosing a map is a good idea. You never know what map you are gonna get and when you see a map you haven't seen in a while, you say: aaaah this one, cool. Some are underwater, some have 0 gravity, others provide you with jetpacks. Big variety there.

Controls:There's only a few buttons you need to play this game. A controller works perfectly fine too. The only downside is that you cannot control the game menu or accept challenges from other players with the controller. That eliminates couch gaming because you always have to have your mouse next to you.

Mechanics:Pick up cubes, bring them back to base, set traps so opponent can't pick up cubes or just shoot at him and kill him. What is not to love there ? The random falling crates also make the matches a lot more fun. The cryo power-up is garbage though. Making you freeze and letting your opponent gear up and collect many cubes while you cannot even move.

And now for the bad things:

Ghost town:I've had this game for 2(?) months and was able to squeeze only 12.7 hours from it. NOBODY plays this game. Don't be fooled by the  12.7 hours though. Half of them were waiting for players to join a server, and I am not ever over exaggerating. Probably even more time was spend only waiting. Oh and I don't mean that there's noone at a certain time of the day. I've tried every hour of the day. It's always a ghost town.

No punishment:There are some players who will play with you for a minute or two and just when you are about to win they will quit the game, giving you 0 XP points and having your time wasted. Great, time to wait another 20 minutes to find a player in the lobby.

Intimidation:Sometimes, very rarely you can find someone on a server, the problem is that nobody wants to play against someone who's played more than 100 games. I've played 244 games and after my 100-150 one it was incredibly difficult convincing anyone to play with me because they feel that I will crush them just because of my big number of games played.

In conclusion:
An incredibly fun game and one of the 3 games I have ever enjoyed the multiplayer of. I am a singleplayer guy and never liked multiplayer, but this game grabbed me and I though that I would play it forever and ever, however NOBODY ELSE PLAYS IT. My suggestion is to buy it ONLY if you are willing to wait in the server lobby for hours every day and eventually finding someone who is not just farming cards or is not intimidated by your playtime.

Since there is no middle ground, I will give it a thumbs up, purchase at your own risk. You might end up not even being able to play it.

reviewText:
It can be fun if you take it for the casual 1x1 multiplayer platformer that it is. The graphics are neato and it works well with a gamepad.

And it's cheap. I bought it for about 2 dollars after a free-weekend, and it came with a 2nd copy as a Gift in a fair attempt to hoist the playerbase. Now that it is 75% off, if you sell the trading cards it'd end up costing you ~25 cents.

The reason i can't recommend it is that there is no playerbase. I've never seen anyone on their servers after the free-weekend last september - not even in 75% off times like now. There is a message in the lobby suggesting you to join the Gun Monkeys Steam Group and check the chatroom to find players. I did that and never found anyone in there either.

Maybe it isn't the developer's fault - for as long as i could play it the game was fine, but unless you fancy playing the tutorial over and over, Gun Monkeys is rendered unusable by this desolation problem.

Then again, maybe it is their fault for releasing a multiplayer-only casual indie game in times when there is such an overabundance of other options. Even the low price doesn't hold much significance if you consider the amount and quality of free-to-play games out there.

reviewText:
Gun Monkeys is a terrible, headache-inducing experience that is a shining example of how not to design a game.

The matchmaking is some of the most confusing I've ever experienced, it took me a good few minutes to figure out how it even worked rather than just randomly accepting any challenges thrown my way. It supports a gamepad but is not a gamepad friendly game. If you have one plugged in it will rumble when you are using mouse and keyboard every time an opponent dies, when you do use the gamepad it will sometime become unresponsive when you launch the game with the gamepad still plugged in.

The chromatic aberration effect mixed with the low field of view causes me such intense eye strain that I can't play for long periods of time. This is the only game I've played that abuses this effect to such levels, even worse than the bloom shader effect fad plaguing every game made during the 2000s.

The controls are horrible and floaty. This video accurately portrays just how it feels trying to manoeuvre and jump around the levels in Gun Monkeys whilst also trying to collecting items (skip to the 0:30 second mark).

reviewText:
Gun Monkeys
Developed by: SIZE FIVE games

“SIZE FIVE was rather inventively set up at the very peak of the Global Economic Meltdown by part-time Indie developer and full-time against-the-grain specialist Dan Marshall.“ The company develops games that arise under the Comedy genre. One of which, winning a BAFTA (British Academy of Film and Television Arts) award. An incredible feat some might say!

Gun Monkeys. Well…, I can honestly say I never thought I was going to see those two words in the same sentence. At first glance, I’d thought a game like this was a little absurd, 2 monkeys fighting in an arena, with guns. Nevertheless, the lovely team at “SIZE FIVE Games” sent me a couple of copies to hand around and spread the word (Thanks by the way!).

Gun Monkeys is an intense, 2D side-scrolling, platform, and shooter. Gun Monkeys is basically a bunch of bad ♥♥♥ monkeys, competing against each other in a 1-on-1 battlefield. Each player has one core, the objective is to maintain your core for as long as you can by returning little power cubes to your core, or (preferred option), annihilating your foes in the arena with an assortment of weapons! If you forget to maintain your core and the power runs out, then your opposition becomes the winner and will proudly shoot your little monkey brains out anytime, vice versa.

My personal experience playing the game was quite pleasant besides the fact that I got absolutely demolished in every round I played. The controls were confusing at first but after a couple of rounds, you get used to it. Graphics wise, the game itself is quite… “trippy”, as it features a lot of glowing colours and blurring, but this can be toned down in the options if you wish.   So, besides the oddly scaled matchmaking, I did enjoy jumping around the randomly generated arena’s, collecting different weapon crates and experimenting with the cool perks that the game allows you to purchase for your character.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a couple of fast-paced, 1 on 1, combat/shooter, arena matches with their friends. If you are going to buy this game, might I recommend buying a second copy for a mate just in case, as the servers are not always filled with people to play against. If you can’t find anyone online, the game also supports 2 players on the one keyboard for some local gaming. On a side note, the narrating of this game is hilarious!

I hope you enjoyed reading my insight on Gun Monkeys, I had a blast playing it!

Regards, Paul

reviewText:
If anyone on Steam wanted to have Gun Monkeys for free by now, they would already have it. Soon after release, the developers began several campaigns to give extra copies of the game for free, and just recently, they gave away a nearly unlimited amount to anyone through PC Gamer. It didn't work. No one plays Gun Monkeys.

The game is simple. You control a monkey, gather energy cubes, use power-ups, and kill the opponent's monkey. As you earn money after each win, you will be allowed to buy unlockable perks and select them for your matches. These perks and power-ups are only OK, and nothing out of the ordinary. Some of them are much more valuable than others, but there is still nothing very fun or interesting about them. You may also customize the color of your monkey, which ensures that you will rarely meet an opponent whose monkey has identical colors. Each level is procedurally generated and filled with platforms and ladders. Some levels have Earth-like gravity, while other levels are in space or underwater. There is only one game mode available, and it's one versus one. If you can find someone to play against that is of the same skill level and with a good ping, there are some short bursts of fun to be had.

The biggest problem with Gun Monkeys is the lack of players. All the free copies given away to the masses only served to be Steam trading card farms. It's obvious that most people run the game with the only goal being to idle for cards. They don't even join the lobby. If you are lucky enough to find someone in the lobby, you better hope they're actually from the same part of the world as the server you're on. If someone joins a server that is not from their region, they ruin the game for everyone, as lag will prevent the game's objectives from actually being attainable. You won't be able to pick up energy cubes at all, for example. The deadly combination of a non-existent playerbase and terrible netcode ensured that Gun Monkeys was a complete failure.

Gun Monkeys is mediocre.

reviewText:
A very simple game with a simple concept.
The idea is to grab up to three power cubes and dump them in your power core, all the while another player is doing the same. By collecting power cubes, you put your power up and decrease the enemy monkey's power by a slight amount.
However; by collecting three, you deal a significant amount of damage to the enemy's power core.
Fighting in the game is quick and tactful, whether it's trying to drop a bomb so it only kills your enemy or gunning from behind cover, the kill will always decrease the enemy's power and cause them to spend time respawning.

Overall, I give it an 8/10
- Good fun
- Funny narrator
- Easy to get the hang of
- Multiple battlefields with different effects in each

x Not much long term replayability
x Don't expect a sequel, or a decent one

reviewText:
A very simple game with a simple concept.
The idea is to grab up to three power cubes and dump them in your power core, all the while another player is doing the same. By collecting power cubes, you put your power up and decrease the enemy monkey's power by a slight amount.
However; by collecting three, you deal a significant amount of damage to the enemy's power core.
Fighting in the game is quick and tactful, whether it's trying to drop a bomb so it only kills your enemy or gunning from behind cover, the kill will always decrease the enemy's power and cause them to spend time respawning.

Overall, I give it an 8/10
- Good fun
- Funny narrator
- Easy to get the hang of
- Multiple battlefields with different effects in each

x Not much long term replayability
x Don't expect a sequel, or a decent one
x Some players are known to disconnect whilst the match is preparing, leaving you connecting with no timeout whilst giving them a win and you a loss as you are forced to quit.

reviewText:
Gun Monkeys is a 2D 1v1 platforming based shooter. That is all it does, and it does it well. There is no single player or co-operative component, no storyline and no other gamemodes, but at $3 a copy, I really can't complain - because what Gun Monkeys does do, it does a very good job of doing.

There are a few issues however, but these are not a fundamental problem with Gun Monkeys, but more with the audience that Gun Monkeys attracts. I should rather say; the lack of audience that Gun Monkeys attracts.

The hardest part about enjoying the game is that there are very few active players to enjoy it with. Luckily, there is none of that matchmaking ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t to struggle with, so if there are players online, you can just connect to a server and challenge whoever else is online to play against.

The core mechanics are great. The art style is exquisite, and the current build of Gun Monkeys is 99% bug-free. You'll have a whole host of interesting perks to buy and utilize, as well as some simple appearance modifiers that serve to enrich your 1v1 matches, which are even better when you have a friend to play against.

My only personal strife with the game is that the perks can be a bit unbalanced, which can be circumvented by just playing with players who are at the same experience level as you are.

There is support for achievements, and it should take around 9-12 hours to get them all (time to win 100 matches). Progression is stored serverside, as is customary with multiplayer games.

I really think Gun Monkeys deserves a look at, and the developer (Dan, from Time, Gentlemen Please! and Been There, Done That) hasn't had the greatest time in terms of sales, so he really deserves your few dollars/euros/rubles.
